title: Protect Yourself from Shark Attacks
brief: Use proven techniques to avoid shark encounters and defend against attacks while in water or raft.
steps: Step 1: Stay with other swimmers for 360-degree watch and group defense.
Step 2: Keep all clothing and shoes on - sharks often attack unclothed people first, especially feet.
Step 3: Avoid urinating except in small amounts, letting it dissipate between discharges.
Step 4: If shark attack imminent in water, splash and yell just enough to keep shark at bay.
Step 5: If attacked, kick and strike shark on gills or eyes if possible.
Step 6: In raft, do not fish when sharks present, keep limbs inside, stay quiet and still.
Step 7: Hit attacking shark with anything available except hands - use oars carefully to avoid breaking them.
warnings: Consider any shark longer than 1 meter dangerous.
Sharks in tropical/subtropical seas are far more aggressive than temperate waters.
If you hit shark on nose, you may injure your hand on its teeth.
Do not throw garbage overboard or clean fish in water when sharks are present.
Bury dead at night if many sharks are in area.
